title: Council member calls for ejecting King after damning misconduct report
text:
King enabled his wife, an official with the high-powered healthcare workers union, 1199 SEIU, to use city resources for private work. | Andrew Burton/Getty Images Council member calls for ejecting King after damning misconduct report

At least one City Council member is calling for the expulsion of Andy King, a Bronx Democrat who reportedly threatened and intimidated staff, interfered in a Council investigation into his conduct and allowed his wife to misuse taxpayer dollars.

Jimmy Van Bramer, a Queens Democrat running for borough president, said Wednesday the Council should remove King if he does not voluntarily resign.

Story Continued Below

“Councilman King’s behavior is horrifying and fundamentally disqualifying: If he does not resign immediately, the Council should expel him,” Van Bramer said in a statement to POLITICO.

“To the employees he abused, degraded, and retaliated against: I’m so sorry you had to go through this,” he added. “To the people he supposedly serves: You deserve better.”

A spokesperson for Council Speaker Corey Johnson said no Council member in recent memory has been suspended, let alone expelled.

In a 48-page report detailing King’s behavior, the Council’s Committee on Standards and Ethics describes how he fostered a culture of fear and intimidation, and he tried to fire employees for cooperating with the Council’s probe into prior complaints about his behavior.

He also forced a staffer to commute two hours to his Bronx district office, reneging on an arrangement that allowed that employee to work in the Council's Lower Manhattan office instead. As a result, according to the report that POLITICO obtained Tuesday night, the employee’s medical appointments were disrupted and the person left the Council’s employ.

This was after he outed the identity of a prior employee who had complained about gender-based harassment by King in 2017. During a meeting in his house that year, he questioned the credibility of that employee to the rest of his staff, the Council found.

King also enabled his wife, an official with the high-powered healthcare workers union, 1199 SEIU, to use city resources for private work.

“Two years after the #metoo movement first went viral, workplace harassment is still rampant and we have to keep pushing for sweeping structural change because it’s not just a few bad apples,” Van Bramer said. “I’m deeply grateful to the workers who refused to stay silent and I stand with you 100 percent.”

King’s office has not returned calls for comment.

The report calls for him to be suspended without pay for 30 days, incur a $15,000 fine and operate under the watch of an outside monitor. The full Council is expected to vote on disciplinary actions next week.
description: Jimmy Van Bramer said Wednesday the Council should remove King if he does not voluntarily resign.
